skill.name: Code Quality Skill
skill.description: Code quality validation, formatting, linting, and pre-commit checks.
skill.summary: Code quality validation, formatting, linting, and pre-commit checks.
skill.author: ByronWilliamsCPA

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation-based skill that only contains a SKILL.md markdown file. It provides instructions for running code quality tools but contains no executable code, file system access, network calls, or environment variable access. The skill poses zero security risk to users.

content.value_statement: This skill helps developers maintain consistent code quality across Python projects. It provides automated checks for formatting, linting, type safety, and pre-commit validation to catch issues before they reach production.
actual_capabilities: Formats Python code using Black and Ruff formatter
Runs linting checks with Ruff including PyStrict rules
Validates type annotations with BasedPyright strict mode
Executes pre-commit hook validation on all files
Enforces naming conventions and error message standards
Detects blind except clauses and debugger statements
limitations: Only supports Python projects with UV package manager
Requires pre-configured pyproject.toml with quality tool settings
Does not fix issues automatically (provides commands for manual execution)
Relaxed rules applied only to test files and scripts

use_cases.title: Maintain code standards
use_cases.description: Ensure all Python code meets project formatting and linting standards before committing.

use_cases.title: CI/CD quality gates
use_cases.description: Run consistent quality checks in CI pipelines to catch issues early in the development workflow.

use_cases.title: Enforce team conventions
use_cases.description: Validate that team contributions follow established coding conventions and best practices.

prompt_templates.title: Quick format check
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to check code formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Check the code formatting in this project. Run black and ruff format to identify any files that need formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Full lint scan
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to run comprehensive linting
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a full linting scan using ruff check. Report all violations and which files need fixes.

prompt_templates.title: Type safety check
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to validate type annotations
prompt_templates.prompt: Run basedpyright to check type safety. Report any type errors or warnings found in the src directory.

prompt_templates.title: Pre-commit validation
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to validate before committing
prompt_templates.prompt: Run all pre-commit hooks on all files. Report which hooks passed and which need attention.

output_examples.input: Check the code formatting in this project
output: Files needing formatting with black: src/module/file1.py, src/module/file2.py
Files needing formatting with ruff format: tests/test_example.py
Run 'uv run black .' and 'uv run ruff format .' to auto-format these files

best_practices: Run ruff check and format commands together for comprehensive quality coverage
Use BasedPyright strict mode to catch type errors early in development
Configure pre-commit hooks to run quality checks before every commit
anti_patterns: Skipping quality checks to save time on deadline-driven projects
Ignoring type warnings from BasedPyright as they may indicate real bugs
Using bare except clauses which bypass error detection and can hide bugs

faq.question: Which Python versions are supported?
faq.answer: Python 3.8 and newer are supported. BasedPyright works best with Python 3.9+ for full type checking capabilities.

faq.question: What line length does this skill enforce?
faq.answer: Black defaults to 88 characters per line. This can be configured in pyproject.toml under the black section.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my CI pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes. Add the quality commands to your CI workflow. Run 'uv run ruff check .' and 'uv run basedpyright src/' as quality gates.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only runs local static analysis tools. No code or data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why are some rules relaxed for test files?
faq.answer: Test files have pragmatic exceptions for patterns that are acceptable in tests but not production code, like simple variable names.

faq.question: How does this compare to other linters like Flake8?
faq.answer: Ruff is 10-100x faster than Flake8 and combines linting, formatting, and import sorting in a single tool with better defaults.
